ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the basic grammer of classical arabic, and read short passages of the Quran and other religous texts
I have learned much vocabulary, dissecting sentence structure, conjugating various verbs in different tenses, and other Arabic grammar rules.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think this should be taught before modern standard arabic or combined with it. Being taught this techincial terms in english is much more efficent than introducing gramatical terms in arbaic and explaning the gramer in arabic.

The strengths of the class are first and foremost Professor Miguel's constant encouragement of learning the language by making mistakes. Next, using classtime to go through the lesson quickly and then working on examples is really helpful to identify mistakes. The class works together for the duration of the class, and I think it builds a strong community.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absulotley. I was thinking of not taking arabic again, but this reinspired me.
If you want to learn Arabic, take this class, but only with Professor Miguel. Not sure how the other instructors are.
